title: Microsoft February 2026 Patch Tuesday: Six Actively Exploited Zero-Days Across Windows Shell, MSHTML, Office, DWM, and Remote Desktop Services (CISA KEV)

sources.name: BleepingComputer - Microsoft February 2026 Patch Tuesday fixes 6 zero-days, 58 flaws
Tenable - Microsoft's February 2026 Patch Tuesday Addresses 54 CVEs

The Hacker News - Microsoft Patches 59 Vulnerabilities Including Six Zero-Days
Krebs on Security - Patch Tuesday February 2026 Edition
Qualys - Microsoft Patch Tuesday February 2026 Security Update Review

timeline.event: Active exploitation of zero-days detected in the wild by multiple threat intelligence firms
CISA adds all six CVEs to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
Microsoft releases February 2026 Patch Tuesday addressing 54-59 CVEs including 6 zero-days
Security research firms publish detailed analyses of all zero-day vulnerabilities
CISA federal patch deadline for all FCEB agencies

simple_summary.what_happened: Microsoft released its February 2026 security update fixing 58 vulnerabilities, including 6 zero-day flaws that hackers were already actively exploiting before the patch was available. Three of these zero-days were publicly known before Microsoft could fix them. CISA has added all six to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog with a March 3 deadline for federal agencies.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Every organization running Windows desktops (Windows 10/11), Windows Server (2012 R2 through 2025), Microsoft Office (365, LTSC 2021/2024, 2016/2019), or Remote Desktop Services. This covers virtually all enterprise Windows environments worldwide.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attackers send phishing emails with malicious links or Office document attachments to targets. Step 2: When victims click links, CVE-2026-21510 bypasses Windows SmartScreen warnings, or CVE-2026-21513 bypasses MSHTML security filters, allowing malware to run without any user warning. Step 3: Malicious Office documents exploit CVE-2026-21514 to bypass OLE protections and execute code silently without the usual security prompts. Step 4: Once inside, attackers use CVE-2026-21519 (DWM type confusion) to escalate from normal user to SYSTEM administrator privileges. Step 5: Attackers leverage CVE-2026-21533 to escalate privileges on Remote Desktop servers, or use CVE-2026-21525 to crash VPN/remote access services and disrupt operations.
what_you_should_do: Deploy February 2026 Patch Tuesday updates to all Windows systems immediately, prioritizing internet-facing and critical systems within 24-48 hours
Block or quarantine Office attachments from external email sources and warn users about clicking links from unknown senders
Enforce MFA on all Remote Desktop Services and restrict RDS access to specific trusted IP ranges
Hunt for indicators of prior compromise: check for Office processes spawning unexpected child processes, DWM privilege escalation attempts, and RasMan service crashes
Disable Internet Explorer mode in Edge and legacy MSHTML rendering where not required by business applications
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Six simultaneously exploited zero-days is an exceptionally high number for a single Patch Tuesday. The combination of security feature bypasses (allowing initial access without warnings) and privilege escalation flaws (enabling full system takeover) creates a devastating attack chain. Threat actors including APT groups are already using these in coordinated campaigns. Every unpatched Windows system is at immediate risk.

tactics.description: CVE-2026-21510 and CVE-2026-21513 enable attackers to bypass SmartScreen and MSHTML security filters via crafted links, allowing malware delivery without security warnings
CVE-2026-21514 allows malicious Office documents to bypass OLE mitigations and execute embedded code without triggering Protected View warnings
Attackers abuse OLE/COM objects in Office documents to execute arbitrary code after bypassing OLE security mitigations
CVE-2026-21519 (DWM type confusion) and CVE-2026-21533 (RDS privilege management flaw) allow escalation from standard user to SYSTEM
Security feature bypasses in SmartScreen and MSHTML allow malicious content to appear trustworthy and avoid detection prompts
CVE-2026-21525 causes null pointer dereference in Remote Access Connection Manager, crashing VPN services and disrupting remote access

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for phishing-based initial access attempts exploiting SmartScreen and MSHTML bypasses, Office documents executing without security prompts, DWM and RDS privilege escalation, and RasMan service crashes indicating DoS exploitation.

log_sources.description: Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) for Office spawning unexpected child processes, and Event ID 4624 for SYSTEM-level logons from standard user processes
RasMan service crash events (Event ID 7034/7036) indicating CVE-2026-21525 exploitation attempts
Alerts for SmartScreen bypass attempts, suspicious OLE/COM object instantiation, and DWM type confusion exploitation
Phishing emails containing malicious .lnk files, Office attachments with embedded OLE objects, or links to MSHTML exploit pages
Event ID 4625 (failed logon) followed by Event ID 4624 with elevated privileges on RDS servers indicating CVE-2026-21533 exploitation

what_to_look_for.indicator: Office process spawning cmd.exe or powershell.exe
what_to_look_for.description: Microsoft Word, Excel, or Outlook launching command-line interpreters indicates successful OLE bypass and code execution via CVE-2026-21514
Shortcut files executing without SmartScreen warning dialog suggests CVE-2026-21510 exploitation

what_to_look_for.indicator: DWM.exe abnormal behavior or privilege escalation
what_to_look_for.description: Desktop Window Manager process exhibiting type confusion or spawning high-privilege child processes indicates CVE-2026-21519 exploitation
Remote Access Connection Manager crashing and restarting indicates CVE-2026-21525 denial-of-service exploitation

what_to_look_for.indicator: RDS session privilege escalation to SYSTEM
what_to_look_for.description: Standard user RDS session gaining SYSTEM privileges indicates CVE-2026-21533 exploitation

immediate_actions.action: Deploy February 2026 Patch Tuesday updates immediately
immediate_actions.description: Apply KB security updates for all Windows systems, prioritizing internet-facing servers and critical infrastructure. Target 24-48 hours for critical systems, 7 days for all systems.
immediate_actions.command: wusa.exe /quiet /norestart (or use WSUS/SCCM/Intune for enterprise deployment)

immediate_actions.action: Block malicious Office attachments at email gateway
immediate_actions.description: Configure email security to quarantine or block Office documents with embedded OLE objects from external senders. Enable attachment sandboxing.

immediate_actions.action: Restrict and harden Remote Desktop Services
immediate_actions.description: Enforce MFA on all RDS sessions, restrict RDS access to specific IP ranges via firewall rules, and disable RDS on systems that do not require it.

immediate_actions.action: Disable Internet Explorer mode and MSHTML rendering
immediate_actions.description: Disable IE mode in Microsoft Edge and legacy MSHTML rendering via Group Policy where not required by line-of-business applications.

Search Windows Security and Application event logs for: Office processes spawning cmd.exe/powershell.exe, DWM type confusion crashes, RasMan service failures, and unexpected SYSTEM-level logons from RDS sessions.
